subject: fix the year 2038 problem in getDateTime
commitMessage:
fix the year 2038 problem in getDateTime

The existing codes cast uint64_t into time_t which is int32_t in
most 32-bit systems. It results overflow if the timestamp is larger
than INT_MAX.
time_t will be 64 bits in future releases of glibc. See
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=28182.

This change workarounds the year 2038 problem via boost's ptime.
std::chrono doesn't help since it is still 32 bits.

Tested on QEMU.
Example output for certificate:
{
  "Name": "HTTPS Certificate",
  "Subject": null,
  "ValidNotAfter": "2106-01-28T20:40:31Z",
  "ValidNotBefore": "2106-02-06T18:28:16Z"
}
Previously, the format is like "1969-12-31T12:00:00+00:00". Note
that the ending "+00:00" is the time zone, not ms.

Tested the schema on QEMU. No new Redfish Service Validator errors.

Signed-off-by: Nan Zhou <nanzhoumails@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>
Change-Id: I8ef0bee3d724184d96253c23f3919447828d3f82

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 1d8782e7a0ed98878bd82c24c7cf830bb8cdc46f by Ed Tanous
Tested? Timestamps formats did not change? No new Redfish Validator error ?
Yep, Gunnar is right.  I was so enamored with the fact that you wrote unit tests in patchset 1 I accidentally overlooked this.  Needs tested somehow and tested statement added.
Done. I added a "tested" section in the commit message.

Just to double check how sure are we that this is producing the same string for non-overfloat ints?  I know the old code had some weirdness around the colon, I'm assuming that isn't needed for the boost version?

I checked the Redfish sepc, it matches. There won't be any millisecond portion. 

Example (got from QEMU): 2106-01-28T20:40:31Z

To be clear, I'd like to check against the old version when compared to the new.  There are some things in the string that are optional, and I'd like to make sure it doesn't change if possible.  Did the old one have milliseconds?

Old format: 
1969-12-31T12:00:00+00:00

New format:
2106-02-06T18:28:16Z

Reading from the Redfish spec, 

YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss[.SSS](Z|(+|-)HH:MM)

SSS is optional. 
Z is equal to +00:00. 

I don't see any obvious mistakes.
do we need the io portion?  posix_time_types.hpp seems like a more specific header for what we need?

https://github.com/boostorg/date_time/blob/develop/include/boost/date_time/posix_time/posix_time.hpp#L24

We need this. "posix_time_types.hpp" is not enough.
ACK

Can we avoid templating this?  I think the only use case we have right now is for uint64_t, right?  I'd really like to avoid someone doing something like uint16_t and expecting it to work right.  Also, int64_t likely has underflow issues, and would be a very easy mistake to make with this as a template.

Yeah, that's a good question. I went with uint64_t before, unfortunately, I am getting many compilation warnings (in the existing codes, we have int64_t, time_t (int32_t), and uint64_t calling this function). 

The boost header should have handled different templates IIUC, right? What's the int64_t underflow here?

> Yeah, that's a good question. I went with uint64_t before, unfortunately, I am getting many compilation warnings (in the existing codes, we have int64_t, time_t (int32_t), and uint64_t calling this function). 

Ideally we'd clean those up, but for the moment, can we just make sure that we only specialize this for those three (int64_t, time_t, and uint64_t) then?  I'd really like to understand where we're using int64_t, that seems odd.  All of dbus should be uint64_t, sys calls should be int32_t/time_t.....  I'm not seeing the int64_t in your patchset.

As I say this, I just realized that if we have a int16_t, it can implicitly convert to int64_t......  so even if we limited the scope, we still get bit by that.

> 
> The boost header should have handled different templates IIUC, right? What's the int64_t underflow here?

getDateTime(-5) will underflow.  I'm not sure boost handles that correctly, and because some of these are being taken from user input (ie untrusted input) we need to be careful of that a little.

> Ideally we'd clean those up, but for the moment, can we just make sure that we only specialize this for those three (int64_t, time_t, and uint64_t) then?  I'd really like to understand where we're using int64_t, that seems odd.  All of dbus should be uint64_t, sys calls should be int32_t/time_t.....  I'm not seeing the int64_t in your patchset.

int64_t is the future std::time_t type.


> getDateTime(-5) will underflow.  I'm not sure boost handles that correctly, and because some of these are being taken from user input (ie untrusted input) we need to be careful of that a little.
I believe Boost should have handled all the integral types. 

Tested: 
crow::utility::getDateTime(-50000LL) => "1969-12-31T10:06:40Z"

> As I say this, I just realized that if we have a int16_t, it can implicitly convert to int64_t......  so even if we limited the scope, we still get bit by that.

Yes, I believe we as long as it compiles, it means boost can handle the Template Instantiation of the corresponding type. The template fits well here given the "boost::posix_time::seconds" itself is using template.

Any more comments?

> > Ideally we'd clean those up, but for the moment, can we just make sure that we only specialize this for those three (int64_t, time_t, and uint64_t) then?  I'd really like to understand where we're using int64_t, that seems odd.  All of dbus should be uint64_t, sys calls should be int32_t/time_t.....  I'm not seeing the int64_t in your patchset.
> 
> int64_t is the future std::time_t type.
> 
> 
> > getDateTime(-5) will underflow.  I'm not sure boost handles that correctly, and because some of these are being taken from user input (ie untrusted input) we need to be careful of that a little.
> I believe Boost should have handled all the integral types. 
> 
> Tested: 
> crow::utility::getDateTime(-50000LL) => "1969-12-31T10:06:40Z"
> 
> > As I say this, I just realized that if we have a int16_t, it can implicitly convert to int64_t......  so even if we limited the scope, we still get bit by that.
> 
> Yes, I believe we as long as it compiles, it means boost can handle the Template Instantiation of the corresponding type.

As with anything, that doesn't mean that it handles it without under/overflowing.

> The template fits well here given the "boost::posix_time::seconds" itself is using template.

If it were just duplicating that template, that might be fine, but as written it's duplicating more than just that instantiation.  Split it into two functions, one in the details namespace taking boost::posix_time::seconds as an argument, then a template that takes a given type.  Alternatively, I think if you just accept boost::posix_time::seconds as the argument, you can brace construct it from the caller and avoid the template entirely.

something like

getDateTime({timestamp});



> 
> Any more comments?
Went with two overloads in details namespace + public template function. Other types will get compilation errors.
That's still going to duplicate the code between the template instantiations, which was the goal of removing the template.  Did the brace construction of the arguments approach above not work?
Brace construction of the arguments doesn't work.
Yeah, I'm seeing that now (still not sure why it doesn't work, but oh well) I think I have something a little better.
Done

Wait.... isn't this wrong in most cases?  EpochTime specifies this as "Time elpased since the Epoch(1 Jan 1970 00:00:00 UTC), in microseconds.", this is taking that value and converting it to seconds, which seems like it would give the wrong answer.  Also, we should rename the variable to make this more clear.  Something like "microsecondsSinceEpoch"

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/7c8c4058e265f784679b9144ff33b89f50f1bf59/http/utility.hpp#L577 The existing code is using "second" as unit.

So LogService has been wrong for some time I guess. I will fix it in the next patchset.

The other places should be good. They have converted the unit into seconds.

> https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/7c8c4058e265f784679b9144ff33b89f50f1bf59/http/utility.hpp#L577 The existing code is using "second" as unit.
> 
> So LogService has been wrong for some time I guess. I will fix it in the next patchset.
> 
> The other places should be good. They have converted the unit into seconds.

Gotta love consistency.  Lets do our best to test and make sure the responses don't change.
Done.
This now looks wrong.  getDateTime now takes seconds since epoch, this gives microseconds since epoch.

Hi Ed, I guess originally it is wrong. https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/7c8c4058e265f784679b9144ff33b89f50f1bf59/http/utility.hpp#L577 The existing code is using "second" as unit.

It should divide by 1000 * 1000 like the other code.
Done
time_t?
Done
See the other note, I still don't like that this duplicates getDateTime between the template instantiations, when all we really need to template create is boost::seconds.
I though we also want to control the type and limit it to time_t and uint64_t.

I said that, and then took it back, but I wasn't very clear on that.  if we support uint16_t and time_t (ie int32_t and int64_t) there's not much reason to limit the input types to anything other than is_integer (which boost::seconds already does) given that any smaller numeric type can implicitly cast to int64/uint64
OK. Does the current implementation look good? We get some benefits from the type limitation since in most cases, people shouldn't use types other than time_t and uint64_t, right?
It's close, but not quite.  The current version still duplicates the template code.  Hang on for 10 minutes, let me push a patch with what I'm thinking.
I see, this does remove a template code.
So here we have an implicit casting, right? From int32 to int64 in 32-bit arm. But it should be safe.
Yes, we are casting int32_t to int64 here.  If we didn't have things using int64_t in places, we could change getDateTimeInt to accept a time_t
Actually, could getDateTimeInt just take time_t?
time_t should work, let me change it.
Done
